comments:
Today, with no apparent cause, my Eclipse (with MyEclipse, but as will be described later, I've eliminated 
MyEclipse as a cause) started displaying dialogs that "an error has occurred" when performing various 
operations (opening files, closing files, committing to CVS). Checking the logs revealed that NPEs were 
occurring in MenuManager.update, essentially whenever I clicked on anything.

Initially I thought perhaps something in my workspace was corrupted, so I quit Eclipse and created a 
new workspace... same problem. Then I freshly unpacked a new Eclipse 3.1 and did not install 
MyEclipse in it, and let it create another new workspace on startup... same problem. I also tried to 
switch the default VM on my Mac OS X 10.4.2 system back to 1.4 (I use 1.5 normally)... same problem. 
So I'm reporting it in the hope that somebody can either figure out what in my configuration that I 
didn't manage to delete is causing the problem, or figure out what in Eclipse is causing the problem.

System information, in case it'll be useful: PowerBook G4, 15", 1.5GHz, 1.5GB memory. It was 1.25GB 
memory until today, but Eclipse was working fine for a while even with the new memory, and it doesn't 
seem to me that that would be likely to cause this sort of issue anyway.


Log produced by Eclipse:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 2 2005-08-03 17:23:07.616
!MESSAGE Job found still running after platform shutdown.  Jobs should be canceled by the plugin that 
scheduled them during shutdown: org.eclipse.ui.internal.progress.ProgressViewUpdater$1

I do not see this problem, and have not heard of this problem before.  By your 
account, there is nothing out of the ordinary with your set-up.  This makes it 
rather hard to figure out what's going wrong.  Can you think of anything?

(In reply to comment #1)
> I do not see this problem, and have not heard of this problem before.  By your 
> account, there is nothing out of the ordinary with your set-up.  This makes it 
> rather hard to figure out what's going wrong.  Can you think of anything? 

Not off the top of my head. As I said, I had been using it without incident for quite some time (and 
continue to do so on my other Mac OS X system)... I upgraded my machine's memory, and upgraded 
WindowShade X to version 4.0.1, but I'm pretty sure the memory doesn't have anything to do with it (a 
memory problem would have other symptoms), and I disabled all application enhancers for Eclipse 
when this problem started to eliminate them as possibilities. 

I was sort of hoping somebody who was familiar with the Eclipse code and architecture might have 
some idea what might cause this problem, and be able to suggest troubleshooting steps. One obvious 
such step is to create a new user account and try a fresh install of Eclipse with that account, and I will 
do that shortly.

OK. After doing some isolation, it appears that WindowShade X 4.0.1 is the cause of the exceptions - 
though I have no idea whatsoever by what mechanism that might be occurring, as WindowShade does 
nothing with menus. Using WindowShade X 3.6, which I had installed before and have now re-installed, 
everything works fine. I will forward all my information about this to Unsanity (the makers of 
WindowShade), so they can try to figure out how WindowShade is causing this.

Thanks for your patience with me on this one...

Moving to SWT just to let you guys know about this potentially bad software  
interaction.  If anyone knows anything particular about WindowShade that might 
be causing this, please let us know.
*** Bug 106714 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I'm experiencing the same symptoms, and also using windowshade 4.0.1.  When I disable windowshade 
eclipse returns to normal.

OS X 10.4.2, Windowshade X 4.0

Will notify Haxie makers.  This is the first real problem I've had with their software.

I downloaded WindowShade 4.0.1 and can reproduce the problem.  We had already
added a check for null MenuItems in the 3.2 stream, but that doesn't explain how
they got there or whether that's the right thing to do anyway.

The problem happens because WindowShade is adding a menu item to the Eclipse menu bar called 
"[WSX]". I am not sure why this item is not visible.
